title: 112_hr3484
content: The Act is titled the "Travel Regional Investment Partnership Act" and includes findings. The "Travel Regional Investment Partnership Act" acknowledges the significance of travel and tourism, highlighting its economic impact. The industry employs millions of Americans, contributes to the GDP, and generates substantial expenditures. However, there have been job losses and declines in tourism output in recent years. In 2009, the travel and tourism industry lost 392,000 jobs and tourism output declined by $100 billion. Total direct tourism employment decreased by 0.5% in 2010. Public-private partnerships are underutilized in promoting travel and tourism, which can help create new domestic tourism markets and promote regional growth. The Domestic Regional Tourism Grant Program is established. The Secretary establishes a grant program through the Office of Travel and Tourism Industries to promote domestic regional tourism growth. Grants range from $100,000 to $1,000,000 and are available to State tourism offices, local destination marketing organizations, and partnerships. Grants under this program can be awarded to State tourism offices, local destination marketing organizations, and partnerships between government entities and tourism organizations. The Secretary may prioritize regions with low tourism marketing contributions, maintain regional diversity, and support rural and less-marketed areas. The grant program prioritizes regions with low tourism marketing contributions, maintains regional diversity, and supports rural and less-marketed destinations. Grants can be used to promote domestic regional tourism growth and create new domestic tourism markets. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant. The grant program prioritizes regions with low tourism marketing contributions, maintains regional diversity, and supports rural and less-marketed destinations. Eligible entities seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary with a description of tourist promotion activities to be funded. The grant program prioritizes regions with low tourism marketing contributions and supports rural destinations. Eligible entities must submit an application with a description of tourist promotion activities to be funded, including partnerships with local tourism entities. The government partners with entities to promote tourism in the domestic region, detailing the partnership agreement, how it will boost regional tourism, and the expected positive impact on job creation. The government requires grant recipients to provide non-Federal matching funds, either in cash or in-kind, equal to the grant amount. The government mandates grant recipients to provide non-Federal matching funds, either in cash or in-kind, equal to the grant amount. A maximum of 25 percent of the required non-Federal matching funds can be in-kind contributions. Additionally, the Secretary must submit a report to Congress detailing travel-generated expenditures and tax receipts within 6 months after grants are awarded. In the fiscal year grants are awarded, the Secretary must report travel-related expenditures, tax receipts, and employment. Definitions include "local tourist entity" and "Secretary." Authorization of appropriations is provided for the first 5 fiscal years. Authorization of $10,000,000 for grants under this section for tourism-related activities, to be used over the first 5 fiscal years after enactment. The Secretary of Commerce is defined as "Secretary."
